Posts.Content: May 17, 2008 11:29PM LAphoenix wrote: Shrink, Congrats on your one-year anniversary!  Time flies when you're having fun, eh?  I just passed my two-year anniversary and started off with a similar diagnosis--3 cm tumor and 25 lymph nodes.  I had a PET scan a month ago and all is NED.  Hope yours goes well, too! Birki, Yeah, the whole Stage III thing is very confusing because different organizations have different definitions.  By some accounts, I would be IIIc because I had more than 10 affected lymph nodes.  Some cancer organizations don't even have a Stage IIIc, however, and don't subdivide by node number.  This is how breastcancer.org defines it: Stage IIIA describes invasive breast cancer in which: Stage IIIB This stage describes invasive breast cancer in which a tumor of any size has spread to the breast skin, chest wall, or internal mammary lymph nodes (located beneath the breast right under the ribs, inside the middle of the chest). By this definition I would be Stage IIIa, but my onc has me down as IIIb.  I've heard that some doctors like to use the higher subdivision as a way to get insurance companies to pay for treatment.   Amy G.

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 10:41AM LAphoenix wrote: Hi Betsy, You can request that your arms be down during the scan.  I did that when I had my first PET scan after surgery.  They wrap you in a pad to keep your arms as close to your trunk as possible, but I actually found that soothing, like a papoose!  I don't get claustrophobic, though, so you might have a different reaction.  Good luck! Amy

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2007 05:26PM LAphoenix wrote: Hi, If you still have a VCR, or can dub one onto DVD, I recommend a video from northamericanrehab.com (I don't know why they don't update to DVD themselves--it's so 20th century!).  My LE therapist uses it in her practice.  The video shows you how to bandage as well as do the massage.  For the massage portion, the therapist demonstrates each step on a "patient."  It's very easy to follow, and the therapist explains the mechanics as you go along.  It helped me when I first was starting with the massage and couldn't always remember the steps, or would get lost in the count.    Here's the website that should take you to the tape purchase ($20).  This company also sells bandages, sleeves, etc. http://www.northamericanrehab.com/NAREHAB_Store/stores/1/Patient-Self-Arm-Bandaging-and-Massage-VHS-Tape-V20-01-P176C44.aspx

LE studies in the news rrs Binney4

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 03:45PM - edited Oct 8, 2007 03:45PM by LAphoenix Hi Debbie, Sorry you're having to deal with lymphedema.  I can recommend a video you can buy online for $20 (and unfortunately it is a video, not a DVD!).  My LE therapist gave me a copy after showing me how to do the self-massage and bandaging.  It's a no-frills production--the patient and nurse stand in front of a stationary camera the entire time--but I found it to be an excellent complement to my therapy sessions.  You can buy it from northamericanrehab.com, in their educational materials section.  If you don't have a VCR anymore, maybe you can have it duped onto DVD.  That's what I did.  Below is a description of the video I copied from the website.  Best of luck! Amy This award winning videotape is narrated by a certified lymphedema therapist and provides step by step, easy to follow instructions on proper arm bandaging and massage techniques. During the bandaging process, the therapist demonstrates self bandaging on herself while discussing important tips.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2008 07:41AM LAphoenix wrote: Kate, I guess I'm the numerical winner here, as I had 25 out of 32 infected nodes!  I'm 22 months post-dx and have had many PET scans, including one a few weeks ago.  As far as anyone can tell, I've been NED since surgery.  Yes, it's likely I had micro-mets, but I also had a lot of chemo and rads, so there's a decent chance these mets were wiped out, or were damaged enough that my own immune system could deal with them.  I'll always be at risk for recurrence, especially as I'm ER+, but I don't feel my node status has doomed me.  My doctors have always been optimistic about my chances.  As others on this thread have stated, stage is only one component of your prognosis.  Keep the faith! Amy
Posts.Title: possible? bapnkat bapnkat

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2008 04:05PM LAphoenix wrote: Floridasurvivor, You've already gotten through 2 years.  Congratulations!  I, too, hate the chest-starers, but I guess it's an unconscious response.       I echo what the others have said about hooking up with other survivors.  There may a Wellness Center in your area, which may have a separate support group for breast cancer survivors.  They also have free yoga and other exercises classes.  Some have support groups for kids, if you're worried about how your diagnosis is affecting your son.  They may also have free one-on-one counseling.   There's a thread here for African American survivors, but you may also find special connection with other Stage IIIers.  We understand the extra fear that comes with this diagnosis.  I call it living in cancer purgatory.  The fear of recurrence is always there, simmering just beneath the surface.  I find it difficult, if not impossible, to talk about it with most people, as it makes them uncomfortable.  And honestly, what can they say?  When the fear gets me, I distract myself with anything that makes me laugh--funny shows, my teenage daughter (when she's not pissed off at me), my dog.  Or small, beautiful things that just make me glad to be in the world--music, flowers, food (chocolate!).  Or I get out and walk.  Or I come here, sometimes just to read and lurk.   Congratulations again on two years and counting!  Be good to yourself.  Many blessings for the new year! Amy G.
Posts.Title: Tryuing to be brave floridasurvivor47 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 08:42PM LAphoenix wrote: Debi, If at all possible I would ask that the area be numbed.  My surgeon literally yanked my drains out without numbing and it was quite painful.  Once they're out, though, it should feel OK.  Just keep the area as dry and clean as you can.      Good luck! Amy G.
Posts.Title: drain in armpit Passenger59 mason204

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 06:07AM LAphoenix wrote: Chattie, It's funny you should ask about this.  Recently I contacted one of the U.S. drs. who has started doing this surgery, Dr. Marga Massey  She's a Duke-trained microsurgeon who works out the Breast Reconstruction Center in Charleston, SC.  (She also has offices in Chicago.)  She told me she became interested in the surgery because so many of her reconstruction patients suffered from LE and she was curious if she could use her skills to help them.  She went to Paris to see a surgeon named Corinne Becker, who pioneered the transfer technique back in the mid-1990s.  Dr. Becker has performed the surgery on thousands of patients in France, and her clinic is well--respected there.  Dr. Massey spent a week at the clinic, talking to patients who had had the surgery, some as long ago as five years.  She was very impressed with what she saw.  Dr. Massey was very honest with me about the limitations and risks of the surgery.  The transfer itself is almost always successful, in terms of vessel connections, etc.  What they do is take 4 or 5 nodes from your groin, with fat, and transfer them to your armpit.  The fat somehow "feeds" the transferred nodes and the nodes grow new channels in your armpit.  Not all women see amazing results, some exerpience no change.  But some are cured, and the majority of them experience significant reduction in swelling and fullness.  It's also good at reducing infections.  There is a slight risk that you might develop leg lymphedema from losing the groin nodes.  She told me she couldn't guarantee that this wouldn't happen but said it's not common.  I would like to ask her or Dr. Becker more about this.  She said there's no way to predict in advance who will benefit the most from the surgery.  But she said she personally has never heard of anyone whose lymphedema got worse as a result.   Dr. Massey is arranging for Dr. Becker to conduct a training clinic in Charleston this fall.  (Apparently Dr. Becker travels around the world showing other microsurgeons how to do the procedure.)  I'm hoping to be one of her "test cases," but the details haven't been worked out with my insurance, so it might not happen.  I would love to try it though, as conventional therapy just hasn't worked well for me.  Maybe the surgery won't work either, but I feel it's worth a shot.  Dr. Massey is a highly skilled, reputable doctor (definitely not a quack!).  She and her breast reconstruction partners (including Dr. Robert Allen) are tops in the DIEP technique.     There is a published study about the surgery in the Annals of Surgery (from 2006 I believe).  It's based on Becker's first patients.  It's written in medicalese so it's not always easy to understand, but you might want to look it up online if you're interested.  I also saw a ten-year follow-up somewhere online.  Both were positive about the procedure. If I hear anything else, I'll let you know. Best, Amy
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Transplant Katiejane LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 03:02PM LAphoenix wrote: Hi Chris, I use a Bio Compression pump and have had reasonably good results with it.  My insurance pays 80% of the monthly rental cost for the machine and paid 80% of the price of the sleeve, new.  All the good pumps are expensive to buy outright ($3,000 and up).  The more chambers the pump has the better.  Bio Compression has one that has eight.  Depending on your insurance, however, you may not have a choice of pumps (kinda like drugs--some insurance companies won't pay for the expensive name brands).  You'll need a doctor's prescription to get one.  My oncologist requested mine.  You do have to commit at least an hour to the pumping, but you can do it while watching TV or reading.  Since your LE is mild, you may only have to do it once or twice a week, for maintanence, along with the massage.  You're lucky your therapist knows how to use one and can show you the ropes.    Good luck with your treatment! Amy G.
Posts.Title: Lymphedema Pump GoodMommy sccruiser

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2007 08:22PM LAphoenix wrote: Roxy, TAC is the most commonly prescribed bc chemo treatment these days.  Stage III women tend to get more of the "T" (Taxol/Taxotere) than others.  I believe the thinking is that even when chemo doesn't completely wipe out the cancer, it does damage and weaken it, making it easier for your own body to fight the disease, or for other treatments like radiation to work.  Personally I don't get the "gloom-and-doom" docs, for all the reasons already stated.  I had 25 infected lymph nodes and my surgeon actually chastised me for being downbeat about my chances (at the time I found that annoying, but I've come to appreciate his attitude more now).  I know it's hard to filter out the statistics and doctors' hand-wringing and not worry, worry, worry.  We all do it.  Finding a balance between realistic concern and informed optimism is hard.   I'm still struggling with that myself.  I do find that being as proactive as possible helps me cope.  There's been another study released (just today as a matter of fact) touting the virtues of weight loss for bc survival, so I'm even more determined to lose some weight and do more exercise.  I take my Femara and Fosamax dutifully (even though the side effects are hard sometimes), take calcium, sit out in the sun a little bit for the vitamin D, drink green tea.  I know none of it is a guarantee, but it makes me feel better knowing I'm doing everything I can to stay healthy (and I am NED 18 months out).  Also, I've found that whenever I'm in pain or really tired, as you are now, I worry more and am more pessimistic.  So I do what I can to get rid of the pain--Advil, exercise, a nice glass of wine, whatever.  You will feel tons better once you're done with chemo.  It might take time to get your strength back and be done with all the side effects, but it will get better.  Can you make vacation plans for the summer?  Planning a summer trip helped me get through the end of my treatment. Good luck and best wishes!  Amy G.
Posts.Title: scared roxy42 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 01:27PM LAphoenix wrote: Chris, While waiting for my insurance to approve my PT sessions, I only did the massage.  It helped a little, but not nearly as much as the wrapping did.  It certainly wouldn't hurt to have your therapist show you how to do it.  The materials will run you about $40, give or take.  If you end up getting a pump, you may not need to do the wrapping, but it will help in the meantime, and for times when you can't pump.  Good luck.  I feel your pain and frustration!  Amy G.
Posts.Title: PT without wrapping GoodMommy inspiewriter

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 07:31PM LAphoenix wrote: Binney, thanks for your thoughts and concerns!  Because up till now Dr. Massey's and Dr. LoTempio's patients have all been reconstruction candidates, the lymph node transfers they've done so far were done during reconstruction surgery.  The Charleston clinic is just now starting to do the node transfer on its own.  I suspect that as far as insurance goes, anyone considering the lymph transfer would have to show that they had tried CDT before getting approval for the surgery.             While I would be one of the first people in the U.S. to have this procedure, Dr. Becker would be performing my surgery, and as I mentioned, she (according to Dr. Massey) has done thousands of them.  I don't feel like I would be a guinea pig.  It does require a very skilled microsurgeon, so it's not something that any surgeon could just pick up and do.  So yes, one needs to be really careful about that.  Just like DIEP reconstruction it will take time for surgeons to become properly trained in the procedure.   Pat, I certainly understand, given your history, why you would be skeptical and questioning.  Ten-year follow-ups have been done, but I don't have complete info on those.  Dr. Massey is an extremely open and generous person, and I'm sure she would be more than happy to talk with you and answer your questions as best she can.  And she's in regular contact with Dr. Becker, so she could ask her about things as well.  At any rate, I will keep you all posted!  Amy
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Transplant Katiejane LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2007 07:18PM LAphoenix wrote: This is a question I've been wondering about a lot lately, although I'm in the opposite situation. I finished active treatment in Feb 07 (Stage IIIb) and have had 2 PET scans and tumor marker tests every month since then. I meet with my onc. or his asst. every month. The second PET scan had a false posititve involving some lymph nodes, which I had to have a CT scan for. Of course, it was nerve-racking waiting for the results. I don't know how I feel about being monitored so closely. Part of me thinks it's a good idea to keep on top of things, while the other part hates the stress it causes. I've heard the argument your onc. probably makes--that it doesn't do any good to catch mets sooner rather than later, that the outcome is the same--but I don't know if I'm convinced by it. A friend made the point that, given how much research is being done and how many new drugs are being tried, it's possible that a treatment for mets that is more effective if used on small or fewer tumors, just might be developed. We're so programmed to think that early detection is better detection that it's hard to accept the more passive approach. I think you can divide oncologists into 2 basic camps--those who are aggressive and pro-active in their treatment, at all stages, and those who view bc as a chronic, long-term disease and have a more "zen" approach. I suspect most patients would be more comfortable with the former approach, but I honestly don't know which is more effective. It drives me crazy, though, that after all these decades of bc research and treatment, the oncology community (NIH, NCI, whatever) hasn't issued guidelines for all doctors to follow regarding post-treatment testing. But obviously there aren't any, because half the doctors do one thing, and the other half do the opposite. I guess you have to decide if the stress of testing would be more or less greater than the stress of waiting for symptoms to appear or not having the temporary peace of mind that negative testing can create. It's a tough choice.
Posts.Title: Follow up Dr Apt margie123 angeldawn

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2008 12:25AM LAphoenix wrote: Welcome back and congratulations on being 3 1/2 years out!  I'm not one of the oldies, and I haven't been in your exact situation, but I understand your hesitancy about returning to your "former life."  In some ways, going back is great because it's proof of your victory over cancer and your fearless commitment to the future.  But I've found being a survivor can also jump-start burnout.  You start to look at how you're spending your time more closely than you did before.  It sounds like you would prefer not to return to the old intensity but are feeling guilty about hanging back.  Maybe you could work something out with your husband and co-workers whereby the business can continue to the next level, with you working fewer hours.  Or maybe you could stick with it until it's reached the next level, with the understanding that if you're not loving it, you can cut back.         Good luck!   Amy G.
